des: Introduces the workings of life from the molecular to the ecosystem level. Topics include genetics, development, ecological interrelationships, evolution, physiology and behavior. A preparatory course intended for all life and health science students.

Introduces the workings of life from the molecular to the ecosystem level. Topics include genetics, development, ecological interrelationships, evolution, physiology and behavior. A preparatory course intended for all life and health science students.

Introduces the workings of life from the molecular to the ecosystem level. Topics include genetics, development, ecological interrelationships, evolution, physiology and behavior. A preparatory course intended for all life and health science students.
Rigorous, in-depth coverage of structure and function of the human body. Laboratories use prosected human body parts. It is recommended that BIOL 1210 is completed prior to taking this course.

The botany and ecology of our regional flora from alpine tundra to salt desert habitats. Numerous afternoon field trips provide the context for learning techniques of plant identification as well as ecological and land use issues concerning Utah's plant communities.

req: "C-" or better in ((BIOL 1210 OR BIOL 1610 OR AP Biology score of 4 or better) AND (CHEM 1110 OR CHEM 1130 OR CHEM 1210 OR CHEM 1211 OR AP Chemistry score of 4 or better)).
"C-" or better in ((BIOL 1210 OR BIOL 1610 OR AP Biology score of 4 or better) AND (CHEM 1110 OR CHEM 1130 OR CHEM 1210 OR CHEM 1211 OR AP Chemistry score of 4 or better)).

des: Clinical experience credit for pre-dental students. Arranged by student with local dentist and through Pre-dental Advising Office. Weekly chair-side observation with a dentist in the community, research paper, and lab projects required. This course is not repeatable for credit and will not count towards a Biology degree.
Topics by arrangement with individual faculty chosen by student.
Research credit by student arrangement with individual faculty and Biology Advising Office.

This course will allow students to earn academic credit for successful completion of a biologically-related internship. The internship progress will be monitored, evaluated, and graded by the course instructor, and internship provider feedback will be considered when determining the final grade. Students must take an active role in finding and applying for an appropriate internship before enrolling for the course.
Research fulfilling Biology requirement for College of Science Honors. Restricted to students in the College of Science Honors Program.
req: Instructor Consent AND Member of Honors College.

des: Restricted to students in the Honors Program working on their Honors degree.
req: Instructor Consent AND Member of Honors College.

des: Repeatable for up to six credit hours. Credit will not be awarded for teaching the same course more than twice. Contact Biology Advising Office for information. Experience in teaching laboratory, discussion, or quiz sections. Arrangements should be made with professor in charge of course.
Topics of special interest taught when justified by student and faculty interest. Content varies from year to year.
